comment.author: 25767425@N02
comment._content: The photographer left his bag in the shot...

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
The photo is dated 11-25-13 -- evidently the date that the Bain News Agency circulated copies of it to their subscribers. It was not taken then, but in October, along with several others in this series that bear the date 10-23-13.

Another annoyingly-underexposed shot of West Point football players:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4525451583/in/photostream/]

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The photographer did not time his exposures properly, so they turned out too damned dark. But at least he was consistent . . .

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Could also be a problem with the scanning of the negative.

comment.author: 75947697@N07
comment._content: The dark appearance of many of these old glass negatives is due to deterioration of the emulsion, not any defect in photographic technique. There are plates from the Civil War collection whose positives look almost completely black.

comment.author: 69438491@N08
comment._content: These LOC reference images are machine-generated, digitally "inverted" (positive) versions of the original glass plate negatives. You generally have to adjust them yourself to get something that looks good. Example of this one in particular: www.shorpy.com/node/12398?size=_original

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: shorpy did a great job with that.
